task.title: Migrate an Image from AWS to Eucalyptus
task.shortdesc: To migrate an image from AWS to Eucalyptus, perform the following steps.

context.note: This example works with an S3-backed Amazon Machine Image (AMI) that you own. For instructions on creating an S3-backed AMI from an existing AMI, see Creating an Instance Store-Backed AMI From an Existing AMI.
Specific examples may vary depending on the distro running on the image that you want to migrate.

step.cmd: Set up your Euca2ools configuration to work with both Eucalyptus and Amazon Web Services. For instructions, see: Set up Euca2ools for AWS.
Check ownership of the AMI that you want to migrate to Eucalyptus by using the euca-describe-images command. For example:

info.codeblock: euca-describe-images --region us-east-1 --owner 999999999999 IMAGE ami-e1a1e888 999999999999/precise-test 999999999999 available private x86_64 machine aki-88aa75e1 instance-store paravirtual xen BLOCKDEVICEMAPPING EPHEMERAL sda2 ephemeral0

step.cmd: Install Euca2ools on the instance. For instructions, see the Euca2ools Guide.
Make sure that you have enough space on a volume to hold the bundle that we will create.
Bundle the running AWS instance. For example:

info.codeblock: sudo -s ec2-bundle-vol -b testbucket -d /mnt -u 4299-4227-3585 -k my-aws.pem -c my-aws-cert.pem -r x86_64 -s 2048 Copying / into the image file /mnt/image... Excluding: /dev/pts / /sys /proc /proc/sys/fs/binfmt_misc /dev /media /mnt /proc /sys /mnt/image /mnt/img-mnt 1+0 records in 1+0 records out 1048576 bytes (1.0 MB) copied, 0.00209056 s, 502 MB/s mke2fs 1.42.3 (14-May-2012) Bundling image file... Splitting /mnt/image.tar.gz.enc... Created image.part.00 Created image.part.01 [example truncated] Created image.part.30 Generating digests for each part... Digests generated. Unable to read instance meta-data for ancestor-ami-ids Unable to read instance meta-data for ramdisk-id Unable to read instance meta-data for product-codes Creating bundle manifest... ec2-bundle-vol complete.

step.cmd: Switch the Euca2ools configuration file to use Eucalyptus. You can do this by specifying the Eucalyptus region as defined in your Euca2ools configuration file by specifying the --region parameter on the command line, or by changing the default-region option in the Euca2ools configuration file:
Download the bundle from the AWS S3 bucket:
Run some checks to make sure that the image can be used with Eucalyptus:

info.codeblock: # sudo mkdir /mnt/aws-image # sudo mount -o loop /tmp/aws-image/image /mnt/aws-image # df -ah …… /tmp/aws-image/image 9.9G 1.1G 8.3G 12% /mnt/aws-image

substep.cmd: Make sure that the distro repositories in the image do not point to EC2-specific repositories.
Install a non-Xen kernel into the image from distro and make sure VirtIO modules are added.

Extract the ramdisk and kernel to be bundled, uploaded and registered as ERI and EKI files. In this example, initrd.img-3.2.0-53-virtual and vmlinuz-3.2.0-53-virtual will be copied from /mnt/aws-image/boot to the /tmp/aws-image directory:
Make sure that the file system of the image is either ext2, ext3, or ext4 by using the file command. For example:

info.codeblock: # file /tmp/aws-image/image /tmp/aws-image/image: Linux rev 1.0 ext4 filesystem data (extents) (large files) (huge files)

step.cmd: Upload the AWS bundled instance to Eucalyptus.
